trans-unit.source: Specifies the type of windows that code is allowed to use.
This enumeration is used by <xref:System.Security.Permissions.UIPermission>.
Users can use all windows and user input events without restriction.
Users cannot use any windows or user interface events.
No user interface can be used.
Users can only use <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.UIPermissionWindow.SafeSubWindows"></xref> for drawing, and can only use user input events for user interface within that subwindow.

Examples of <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.UIPermissionWindow.SafeSubWindows"></xref> are a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox"></xref>, common dialog controls, and a control displayed within a browser.

Users can only use <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.UIPermissionWindow.SafeTopLevelWindows"></xref> and <xref href="System.Security.Permissions.UIPermissionWindow.SafeSubWindows"></xref> for drawing, and can only use user input events for the user interface within those top-level windows and subwindows.
When it runs under SafeTopLevelWindows permission, your application:
Will show the DNS name or IP address of the Web site from which the application was loaded in its title bar.
Will display Balloon tool-tip when it first displays, informing the user that it is running under a restricted trust level.
Must display its title bar at all times.
Must display window controls on its forms.
Cannot minimize its main window on startup.
Cannot move its windows off-screen.
Cannot use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.Opacity%2A> property on <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.Opacity%2A> to make its windows less than 50% transparent.
Must use only rectangular windows, and must include the window frame.
Windows Forms will not honor setting <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.FormBorderStyle%2A> to `None`.
Cannot make windows invisible.
Any attempt by the application to set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Visible%2A> property on its <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> objects to `False` will be ignored.
Must have an entry in the Task Bar.
Will have its controls prohibited from accessing the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Parent%2A> property.
By implication, controls will also be barred from accessing siblings - i.e., other controls at the same level of nesting.
Cannot control focus using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Focus%2A> method.
Will have restricted keyboard input access, so that a form or control can only access keyboard events for itself and its children.
Will have restricted mouse coordinate access, so that a form or control can only read mouse coordinates if the mouse is over its visible area.
Cannot set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.TopMost%2A> property.
Cannot control the z-order of controls on the form using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.BringToFront%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.SendToBack%2A> methods.
These restrictions help prevent potentially harmful code from spoofing attacks, such as imitating trusted system dialogs.
